history.content:
Hi —

Since it went to sleep yesterday afternoon the balloon travelled about 1200km on an South-East-East path. It woke up this morning 4:40am pacific time and was received by stations across both side of the Atlantic Ocean. Today it leisurely travelled mostly east for about 600KM till it went to sleep around 11am pacific time. From now on, we should expect the balloon to be active earlier and earlier as it moves through time-zones. 
Our naive balloon does not know that it is being chased by another balloon! On Saturday morning, the SF-HUB (https://sf-hab.org) group released a balloon from the Berkeley marina. The balloon, W6MRR-22, has taken a slightly different path and is now tailing out baloon 300KM to the east. W6MRR is carrying a lighter load, and is filled with Hydrogen gas, and therefore travels higher than ours.  I truly recommend checking out the information at https://sf-hab.org, these folks are real expert (amateur) operators!.
You can see the path of both balloons here: https://aprs.fi/#!call=a%2FNU6XB-14%2Ca%2FW6MRR-22&timerange=604800&tail=604800
The predictions for our balloon are attached below. There are two major paths it could take — either east or north. There’s quite a bit of uncertainty. A map of the winds at 9000m can explain this  and is also attached. Feel free to bet!
More tomorrow.
— Miki
history.subject: EECS Balloon, day 5 -- mid Atlantic chase
